overview_of_class:
The Many Faces of Roman Egypt: Materials Science and Socioeconomics of Portrait Mummies from Ancient Fayum

In this unique one-time seminar, we will look at the role scientific examination plays in investigating the production of ancient Egyptian mummy portraits and how these objects fit into the larger socioeconomic context of Roman Egypt in the 2nd century CE. These explorations will be presented in an exhibition at the Block Museum during Winter 2018. Students will have the opportunity for hands-on work in a laboratory environment with an actual mummy from this period to assess how it was made, used, and buried, and what these data mean in a wider archaeological context. Students will gain insight into and actively contribute to exhibition layout and interpretation, and publicly share their research through a public program in winter 2018.

overview_of_class: This course examines one of the most important ideals of our time?freedom?within the context of slavery and religion. Rather than assuming slavery and freedom are unrelated opposites, this class focuses on the relationship between freedom and slavery within the context of religion and philosophy from ancient to modern times. Four general periods receive focus: antiquity, medieval, early modernity, and developments since the nineteenth century. The course readings will focus on key themes that include: the role of slavery and freedom in religious traditions; Hegel's conception of freedom and slavery; the Haitian Revolution; slavery and abolition; the causal relation between slavery and freedom; gender and reform movements and their relation to slavery and feminism; the sex-trade and slavery; and recent movements for abolition democracy.

Four general periods receive focus: antiquity, medieval, early modernity, and developments since the nineteenth century. The course readings will focus on key themes that include: the role of slavery and freedom in religious traditions; Hegel's conception of freedom and slavery; the Haitian Revolution; slavery and abolition; the causal relation between slavery and freedom; gender and reform movements and their relation to slavery and feminism; the sex-trade and slavery; and recent movements for abolition democracy.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students will understand the early and contemporary philosophies of freedom and slavery through the influences of such authors as Plato, Aristotle, and Hegel

Students will be able to discuss and analyze the impact or racial slavery on the history of freedom and slavery

Students will be able to assess and develop arguments concerning the causal relationship between freedom and slavery

Students will assess scholarly arguments concerning freedom and slavery in relation to gender

Students will be able to explain and assess histories of slavery and freedom in non-Western context

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
Discussion: Students will participate in class discussions based on assigned readings
Lecture: Two 70-minute lectures weekly
Readings: Assigned class readings for all class meetings
Writing assignments: Two response papers (500 words)

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Assigned readings include:
Saidiya Hartman, Scenes of Subjection
Susan Buck-Morris, Hegel and Haiti
Hegel, selections from the Phenomenology of Spirit
Aristotle, Book I of the Politics
Paul of Tarsus, New Testament letters
Orlando Patterson, Freedom in the Making of Western Culture
Elizabeth Anderson, "The Social Epistemology of Morality: Learning from the Forgotten History of the Abolition of Slavery"
Condorcet, Reflexions sur l'esclavage des negres, trans. (In Sala-Molins 2006)
C. L. R. James, The Black Jacobins
David Brion Davis, The Problem of Slavery in Western Culture
DuBois, "The Suppression of the African Slave Trade" and "John Brown"
